identificationModule.briefTitle: Longitudinal Study of Intra-Uterine Growth Restriction
identificationModule.officialTitle: Longitudinal Study of Intra-Uterine Growth Restriction (IUGR)

descriptionModule.briefSummary: The investigation will employ a longitudinal approach in which every fetus diagnosed to be SGA (Small for Gestational Age ) will be studied at frequent intervals with sophisticated imaging techniques to assess subtle physiologic changes in the brain, heart, and placenta over time. These findings will be correlated with neurological and cardiovascular function in the newborn and early childhood. This research initiative should yield diagnostic and therapeutic templates that will improve the quality of life of IUGR babies in addition to providing important information that will better inform current diagnostic practices.
descriptionModule.detailedDescription: The overarching objective is to serially assess changes in the fetal circulation, heart, and brain with sophisticated ultrasound, MRI (Magnetic Resonance Imaging), and body composition techniques that will provide clues as to how growth restricted babies will tolerate life outside the uterus. Employing a longitudinal study will allow the investigators to correlate perinatal and postnatal outcomes more comprehensively than previous studies.

bioSpec.description: Maternal peripheral blood and umbilical cord blood

armGroups.label: Small for Gestational Age Pregancies (controls)
armGroups.description: Small for gestational age (SGA) pregnancies that do not develop IUGR will be considered controls. Each subject will have an ultrasound, MRI, maternal blood and cord blood collection, placental analysis, neurological function assessments (infant), and body fat measurements (infant).

armGroups.label: IUGR Pregnancies (cases)
armGroups.description: Small for gestational age (SGA) pregnancies that do develop IUGR will be considered cases. Each subject will have an ultrasound, MRI, maternal blood and cord blood collection, placental analysis, neurological function assessments (infant), and body fat measurements (infant).

interventions.name: Ultrasound
interventions.description: With 3-D and 4-D high-resolution color Doppler methods it is possible to map out the placental circulation, fetal circulation, fetal brain, and fetal cardiac function. Investigators will collect these data points prenatally.

interventions.name: MRI
interventions.description: Similar to the Ultrasound data, investigators will collect MRI images of the fetal brain and the placenta. MRI will allow investigators to collect more detailed images of both the fetal brain and placenta, and investigators will be utilizing this technique both prenatally and postnatally.

interventions.name: Blood collection
interventions.description: The maternal and cord blood will be collected for the processing of plasma and serum. There may be early biomarkers of IUGR in the maternal circulation that investigators can use to better determine the appropriate strategy for clinical management of care. Collection and subsequent analysis of molecular markers in the umbilical cord blood will be used to further confirm physiological dysfunction as detected by ultrasound and MRI techniques.

interventions.name: Neurological Function Assessment
interventions.description: Neurological development tests including a Bayley exam, Mullen exam, Developmental Profile-3, Child Behavior Checklist, and Pediatric Stroke Outcome Measure (PSOM) will be performed.

interventions.name: Placental Analysis
interventions.description: Placentas will undergo pathological evaluation for placental function.

interventions.name: Measurement of body fat
interventions.description: The baby's body fat will be measured in a special incubator called a PEAPOD or BODPOD when an infant.

interventions.name: Pediatric heart ultrasound
interventions.description: Children will have ultrasounds of their hearts during follow-up visits.

primaryOutcomes.measure: Characterize the sequence of neurological and cardiovascular events defining early and late IUGR pathogenesis, respectively
primaryOutcomes.description: Using ultrasound and MRI to identify changes in the fetal vasculature, and fetal brain as early and late IUGR progress.
primaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Every two weeks from the time of IUGR diagnosis or first visit

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Correlate in utero adaptations in early and late IUGR, to infant and early childhood neurodevelopment
secondaryOutcomes.description: Assess neurodevelopment with a series of tests (PSOM, Bayleys III, Mullen's Scale of Early Learning, Developmental Profile-3, Child Behavior Checklist) and correlate neurological in utero findings to neurodevelopment outcomes after birth.
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Baseline (Day 0), 40-44 weeks gestational age (post-birth), 6 months, 1-7 years

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Correlate in utero adaptations in early and late IUGR, to infant and early childhood cardiovascular outcomes
secondaryOutcomes.description: Assess cardiovascular health via heart ultrasound after birth
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Baseline (Day 0), 40-44 weeks gestational age (post-birth), 6 months, 1-7 years

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Correlate in utero adaptations in early and late IUGR, to infant and early childhood metabolic outcomes
secondaryOutcomes.description: Correlate IUGR severity to metabolic outcomes as assessed by body composition (pea pod and bod pod with a pediatric attachment), anthropometrics, and a diet questionnaire after birth.
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Baseline (Day 0), 40-44 weeks gestational age (post-birth), 6 months, 1-7 years

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Compare early IUGR, late IUGR and SGA infant and early childhood outcomes
secondaryOutcomes.description: Using the tests describe above compare the outcomes of each group after birth.
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Baseline (Day 0), 40-44 weeks gestational age (post-birth), 6 months, 1-7 years

eligibilityModule.eligibilityCriteria:
Inclusion Criteria:

* Patients with diagnosed SGA by an ultrasound estimated fetal weight (EFW) of less than the 10th percentile or a fetal abdominal circumference of less than the 5th percentile will be included in the study at the time of their first examination.

Exclusion Criteria:

* Patients \< 18 years of age, and chromosomal anomalies as identified by regular aneuploidy screening.
eligibilityModule.studyPopulation: University of Colorado School of Medicine is a referral center for women carrying fetuses with IUGR. Care providers routinely evaluate more than 300 patients per year at our outreach sites alone whose fetuses have estimated fetal weights below the 10th percentile. Of these, the investigators will initially enroll 200 patients per year between 24 and 36 weeks over a two-year period.

locations.facility: University of Colorado Denver Anschutz Medical Campus
